events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker explains that in December, the northern hemisphere is tilted away from the sun while the southern hemisphere is tilted towards it. The speaker clarifies that the tilt stays the same, but the earth's position in its orbit around the sun causes the difference. He adds that the rotational axis still points in the same direction in both summer and winter. The clip ends with the male speaker sighing.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining the definition of a solar day, and describing it as the time span between the sun taking the same position on two consecutive days.  He continues, mentioning that the Earth's orbit around the sun causes a difference between a solar day and a sidereal day, which he then defines as Earth's rotation relative to the stars. He further explains that looking at the sky and seeing certain stars at a position, shows the same position the next day after 23 hours and 56 minutes, and due to that difference, every day has roughly 4 minutes of difference over 365 days, adding up to an additional rotation. He finishes by thanking the listener for watching and saying goodbye.
